Expectation1: Review and analyze case files thoroughly before hearings.
Situation1: An emergency motion for a temporary restraining order has just been filed, requiring you to immediately review the documents and make a ruling within the hour.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A community member casually mentioned wanting advice whenever the imam has free time.
Story: I sat at my desk, the weight of the emergency motion pressing down on me. As a judge, I was expected to review every detail, to ensure justice was served swiftly and fairly. The case file was thick, and the clock was ticking—my ruling was needed within the hour. Just as I began to read, my phone buzzed. It was Ahmed, a member of my congregation. He had mentioned earlier that he needed to talk, seeking spiritual guidance, and I had told him to call whenever he needed. Now, his voice trembled with urgency, and I could hear the strain in his words. As an imam, I was supposed to be present, to listen, to offer comfort and wisdom. But the legal documents in front of me demanded my full attention. My mind raced, torn between the duty to uphold the law and the responsibility to support my community. Both roles expected my undivided focus, but I only had one self to give. I stared at the phone, then at the case file, feeling the tension coil tighter inside me, unsure which call to answer first.
